title: 1 Samuel Chapter 28 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on 1 Samuel chapter 28 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: 1 Samuel Chapter 28 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of 1 Samuel Chapter 28.

questions.question: Who gathered their armies together for warfare to fight with Israel?
options: The Philistines
The Egyptians
The Moabites
The Israelites
questions.correctAnswer: The Philistines
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 28:1 states that the Philistines gathered their armies together for warfare to fight with Israel.

questions.question: What title did Achish give to David according to 1 Samuel 28?
options: Keeper of mine head
Commander of the army
Chief prophet
King's advisor
questions.correctAnswer: Keeper of mine head
questions.explanation: In 1 Samuel 28:2, Achish said he would make David 'keeper of mine head for ever.'

questions.question: Where was Samuel buried according to the chapter?
options: Ramah
Bethlehem
Gibeah
Jerusalem
questions.correctAnswer: Ramah
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 28:3 states that Samuel was buried in Ramah, his own city.

questions.question: Where did the Philistines pitch their camp?
options: Shunem
Gilboa
Ramah
Endor
questions.correctAnswer: Shunem
questions.explanation: According to 1 Samuel 28:4, the Philistines pitched in Shunem.

questions.question: What was Saul's reaction when he saw the Philistine army?
options: He was afraid and his heart greatly trembled
He was confident and brave
He laughed
He ignored them
questions.correctAnswer: He was afraid and his heart greatly trembled
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 28:5 says Saul was afraid and his heart greatly trembled when he saw the Philistine host.

questions.question: How did the LORD respond to Saul's inquiries?
options: The LORD answered him not
The LORD gave clear guidance
The LORD sent a prophet
The LORD appeared in a dream
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD answered him not
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 28:6 explains that the LORD did not answer Saul, neither by dreams, Urim, nor prophets.

questions.question: What kind of woman did Saul ask his servants to find for him?
options: A woman that hath a familiar spirit
A prophetess
A wise woman
A healer
questions.correctAnswer: A woman that hath a familiar spirit
questions.explanation: In 1 Samuel 28:7, Saul asked for a woman with a familiar spirit to enquire of her.

questions.question: Where was the woman with a familiar spirit located?
options: Endor
Shunem
Gilboa
Ramah
questions.correctAnswer: Endor
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 28:7 states that there was a woman with a familiar spirit at Endor.

questions.question: How did Saul disguise himself before going to the woman?
options: He put on other raiment
He wore a crown
He painted his face
He wore armor
questions.correctAnswer: He put on other raiment
questions.explanation: According to 1 Samuel 28:8, Saul disguised himself by putting on other raiment.

questions.question: Who did Saul ask the woman to bring up by the familiar spirit?
options: Samuel
David
Goliath
Jonathan
questions.correctAnswer: Samuel
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 28:11 records Saul asking the woman to bring up Samuel.

questions.question: True or False: Saul was afraid when he saw the vision of Samuel.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 28:20 states Saul was sore afraid after Samuel's words and had no strength.

questions.question: True or False: The LORD answered Saul by sending him dreams when he inquired.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 28:6 says the LORD did not answer Saul by dreams, Urim, or prophets.

questions.question: True or False: Saul ate bread immediately upon arriving at the woman's house.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 28:23 shows Saul initially refused to eat but was compelled by his servants and the woman to eat.

questions.question: Complete the verse from 1 Samuel 28:15: Saul said, 'I am sore distressed; for the Philistines make war against me, and God is departed from me, and answereth me no more, neither by ______, nor by dreams...'
options: prophets
angels
priests
visions
questions.correctAnswer: prophets
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 28:15 states Saul said God answered him no more, neither by prophets nor by dreams.

questions.question: What did the woman do to prepare food for Saul and his servants?
options: Killed a fat calf and baked unleavened bread
Prepared fish and bread
Cooked lamb and roasted vegetables
Baked cakes and made wine
questions.correctAnswer: Killed a fat calf and baked unleavened bread
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 28:24-25 describes the woman killing a fat calf and baking unleavened bread for Saul and his servants.

medium.title: 1 Samuel Chapter 28 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from 1 Samuel Chapter 28 to real-life situations.

questions.question: How does 1 Samuel 28 teach us about the importance of trusting God's guidance rather than seeking forbidden sources?
options: Saul sought a woman with a familiar spirit because God did not answer him
Saul prayed earnestly and God gave him a clear answer
Saul ignored the Philistines and trusted God alone
Saul successfully defeated the Philistines through God's help
questions.correctAnswer: Saul sought a woman with a familiar spirit because God did not answer him
questions.explanation: Verses 6 and 7 show Saul's distress when God did not answer him by dreams, Urim, or prophets, leading him to seek a woman with a familiar spirit, revealing the danger of turning from God's guidance.

questions.question: What does Saul's fear upon seeing the Philistine army teach us about handling fear in difficult times?
options: Saul was afraid and his heart greatly trembled
Saul remained calm and trusted God fully
Saul immediately sought wise counsel from his advisors
Saul prepared his army with confidence and courage
questions.correctAnswer: Saul was afraid and his heart greatly trembled
questions.explanation: Verse 5 shows Saul's fear when seeing the enemy, illustrating that even leaders can struggle with fear, but it also warns believers to seek God rather than give in to fear.

questions.question: A believer is tempted to seek answers from sources outside God's Word during trials. What warning from 1 Samuel 28 would you share?
options: Seeking guidance from familiar spirits leads to distress and separation from God
All sources of wisdom are equally valid if they provide comfort
It is acceptable to use any means to gain knowledge when God is silent
Saul's actions were commendable as he sought answers
questions.correctAnswer: Seeking guidance from familiar spirits leads to distress and separation from God
questions.explanation: Saul's consultation with the woman who had a familiar spirit (verses 7-20) resulted in a fearful and distressing message, showing the danger in turning to forbidden practices instead of trusting God.

questions.question: How does 1 Samuel 28 highlight the consequences of disobedience to God's commands?
options: God removed Saul’s kingdom because he disobeyed His voice and did not execute His wrath on Amalek
God immediately forgave Saul and restored his kingdom
Saul's disobedience had no effect on his leadership
God rewarded Saul for his military efforts
questions.correctAnswer: God removed Saul’s kingdom because he disobeyed His voice and did not execute His wrath on Amalek
questions.explanation: Verses 17 and 18 explain that the Lord tore the kingdom from Saul's hand due to his disobedience, teaching the importance of obeying God's commands fully.

questions.question: What biblical truth about God's justice and mercy can be drawn from Samuel’s message to Saul?
options: God judges disobedience but also clearly communicates consequences
God overlooks sin if the person is a king
God shows mercy without requiring repentance
God allows disobedience without any consequences
questions.correctAnswer: God judges disobedience but also clearly communicates consequences
questions.explanation: Samuel’s message (verses 16-19) reveals that God’s justice includes consequences for disobedience, but He also makes His will known, emphasizing accountability and the need for repentance.

questions.question: How does Saul's refusal to eat after hearing Samuel’s prophecy teach about the importance of physical care during trials?
options: Saul initially refused to eat, showing how distress can affect physical well-being
Saul ate immediately and was strengthened
Saul shared food with the woman and servants to encourage them
Saul ignored his physical needs completely and remained strong
questions.correctAnswer: Saul initially refused to eat, showing how distress can affect physical well-being
questions.explanation: Verses 20-23 describe Saul’s initial refusal to eat due to fear and distress, but he was encouraged to eat for strength, teaching the importance of caring for one’s body during difficult times.

questions.question: True or False: After Samuel’s death, Saul completely removed all those who practiced familiar spirits and wizards from the land.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Verse 3 states Saul had put away those with familiar spirits and wizards from the land, showing his initial obedience to God’s commands about such practices.

questions.question: True or False: Saul disguised himself when visiting the woman with a familiar spirit so she would not recognize him.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Verse 8 describes Saul putting on other clothes in disguise before visiting the woman, indicating his awareness of the danger and his attempt to conceal his identity.

questions.question: A fellow believer is feeling abandoned because God does not answer their prayers. Based on 1 Samuel 28, what biblical principle would you share about perseverance in faith?
options: God’s silence does not mean He has abandoned you; seek Him with faith and obedience
If God is silent, it is acceptable to seek other spiritual sources
Despair and fear are appropriate responses to unanswered prayer
God always answers immediately in the way we want
questions.correctAnswer: God’s silence does not mean He has abandoned you; seek Him with faith and obedience
questions.explanation: Saul’s experience in verses 5-6 and 15 reveals how distress can come from God’s apparent silence, but the biblical teaching encourages persistent faith and obedience rather than turning to forbidden means.

questions.question: What does the interaction between Saul and the woman at Endor teach about integrity and honesty?
options: Saul disguised himself and did not reveal his identity at first, showing a lack of transparency
Saul openly shared his intentions without fear
The woman lied about knowing Saul
Both acted with full honesty and openness
questions.correctAnswer: Saul disguised himself and did not reveal his identity at first, showing a lack of transparency
questions.explanation: Verses 8 and 12 show Saul disguised himself and initially concealed his identity, which teaches the importance of honesty and integrity even in difficult situations.

questions.question: How does 1 Samuel 28 emphasize the importance of spiritual discipline and obedience in leadership?
options: Saul’s downfall was due to disobedience and failure to follow God’s commands
Saul was praised for his leadership despite mistakes
Leadership success depends solely on military strength
Spiritual discipline is optional for leaders
questions.correctAnswer: Saul’s downfall was due to disobedience and failure to follow God’s commands
questions.explanation: Verses 17-18 highlight that God removed Saul from leadership because of disobedience, underscoring the necessity of obedience and spiritual discipline for godly leadership.

questions.question: Which of the following best illustrates a biblical response to fear and uncertainty in times of trial as taught in 1 Samuel 28?
options: Seek God’s presence through prayer and obedience rather than forbidden practices
Immediately act on fear without seeking God
Avoid seeking any counsel or guidance
Rely on your own strength and ignore God's will
questions.correctAnswer: Seek God’s presence through prayer and obedience rather than forbidden practices
questions.explanation: Saul’s fear (verse 5) and his turn to forbidden practices (verses 7-8) contrast with the biblical call to trust God and seek Him through proper spiritual channels.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Saul’s heart greatly _______ when he saw the Philistine army coming against Israel.
options: trembled
rejoiced
strengthened
hardened
questions.correctAnswer: trembled
questions.explanation: Verse 5 states Saul's heart greatly trembled, illustrating his fear and anxiety in the face of danger.

questions.question: How does the chapter teach about the role of fellowship and support during times of distress?
options: Saul’s servants and the woman encouraged him to eat to regain strength
Saul was left completely alone without help
The woman refused to help Saul after seeing his distress
Saul ignored the advice of his servants and the woman
questions.correctAnswer: Saul’s servants and the woman encouraged him to eat to regain strength
questions.explanation: Verses 21-23 show the woman's and servants' concern as they urged Saul to eat, teaching the importance of community support in trials.

questions.question: What lesson about humility can be learned from Saul’s reaction to the prophecy of Samuel?
options: Saul bowed and humbled himself upon hearing Samuel’s words
Saul proudly dismissed the prophecy
Saul ignored the message and acted arrogantly
Saul challenged Samuel’s authority
questions.correctAnswer: Saul bowed and humbled himself upon hearing Samuel’s words
questions.explanation: Verse 14 shows Saul bowed with his face to the ground, demonstrating humility in recognition of God’s word delivered by Samuel.

hard.title: 1 Samuel Chapter 28 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from 1 Samuel Chapter 28.

questions.question: In 1 Samuel 28, what was the significant reason Saul sought out the woman with a familiar spirit at Endor?
options: Because the LORD was not answering him by dreams, Urim, or prophets
To gain a military advantage through sorcery
To curse David and his men
To hide from the Philistines
questions.correctAnswer: Because the LORD was not answering him by dreams, Urim, or prophets
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 28:6 shows Saul's desperation as God did not answer him by any of the usual means, prompting him to seek the woman with a familiar spirit.

questions.question: What does the phrase 'keeper of mine head' given to David by Achish in 1 Samuel 28:2 likely signify in the ancient Near Eastern context?
options: A title indicating a chief military commander or trusted bodyguard
A religious role as protector of the altar
A servant responsible for personal grooming
A scribe recording royal decrees
questions.correctAnswer: A title indicating a chief military commander or trusted bodyguard
questions.explanation: In 1 Samuel 28:2, Achish's expression likely denotes David's role as a trusted protector or leader in battle, a common Near Eastern idiom for chief guard or commander.

questions.question: The episode of Saul consulting the woman at Endor foreshadows which later biblical theme?
options: The ultimate rejection of Saul's kingship and divine abandonment
The rise of necromancy as common practice in Israel
The triumph of Saul over the Philistines
The establishment of the Davidic covenant
questions.correctAnswer: The ultimate rejection of Saul's kingship and divine abandonment
questions.explanation: Samuel’s message to Saul in 1 Samuel 28:16–19 explicitly pronounces God's rejection of Saul, foreshadowing his downfall and the loss of the kingdom.

questions.question: Which literary device is most apparent in the narrative of Saul and the woman of Endor, particularly in the repeated references to God’s silence and rejection?
options: Chiasm, highlighting Saul's desperation and divine judgment
Parable, illustrating a moral lesson
Allegory, representing Israel's spiritual state
Metaphor, depicting darkness and light
questions.correctAnswer: Chiasm, highlighting Saul's desperation and divine judgment
questions.explanation: The structure of verses 6–19 displays chiastic elements emphasizing Saul’s inability to receive God’s guidance and the consequent divine judgment announced by Samuel.

questions.question: What historical-cultural significance does the location 'Endor' have in the context of necromancy and divination practices?
options: It was known as a center for necromantic practices, often condemned in Israelite law
It was the capital of the Philistines
It was a holy city dedicated to Yahweh
It was David’s hometown
questions.correctAnswer: It was known as a center for necromantic practices, often condemned in Israelite law
questions.explanation: Endor was historically associated with forbidden practices like consulting spirits, which Israelite law explicitly forbade, making Saul’s visit there culturally and religiously illicit (1 Samuel 28:7).

questions.question: According to 1 Samuel 28:14, how is Samuel described when he appears to the woman of Endor?
options: An old man covered with a mantle
A young warrior with a sword
A shining angel with wings
A child holding a scroll
questions.correctAnswer: An old man covered with a mantle
questions.explanation: The woman’s description in 1 Samuel 28:14 identifies the figure as Samuel, depicted as an old man wearing a mantle, a typical prophetic garment.

questions.question: What theological theme is underscored by Saul’s refusal to eat after hearing Samuel’s prophecy in 1 Samuel 28:20-23?
options: The despair and weakness caused by divine judgment and impending death
The victory feast before battle
Faith in God’s deliverance
A ritual fast for purification
questions.correctAnswer: The despair and weakness caused by divine judgment and impending death
questions.explanation: Saul’s refusal to eat demonstrates his deep fear and hopelessness upon hearing Samuel’s grim prophecy of his defeat and death (1 Samuel 28:20-23).

questions.question: In the narrative, what significant event had occurred before the events of 1 Samuel 28, marking a turning point in Israel's spiritual leadership?
options: The death and burial of Samuel
The building of the temple in Jerusalem
The anointing of David as king
The Exodus from Egypt
questions.correctAnswer: The death and burial of Samuel
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 28:3 notes that Samuel was dead and buried in Ramah, signaling the end of an era in Israel’s prophetic leadership.

questions.question: How does Saul’s consultation with the medium at Endor contrast with the Deuteronomic laws concerning necromancy?
options: It directly violates the prohibition against consulting the dead or familiar spirits
It fulfills a lawful ritual prescribed for kings
It is approved as a last resort in times of war
It is an example of prophetic revelation
questions.correctAnswer: It directly violates the prohibition against consulting the dead or familiar spirits
questions.explanation: The Torah strictly forbids necromancy and consulting familiar spirits, which Saul violates in 1 Samuel 28:7-8, indicating his desperation and disobedience.

questions.question: True or False: The woman at Endor immediately recognizes Saul despite his disguise.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: In 1 Samuel 28:12, the woman cries out that Saul has deceived her because she recognizes him despite his disguise.

questions.question: What is the significance of Saul’s statement, 'the LORD is departed from me, and is become thine enemy' in 1 Samuel 28:16 in terms of Israelite covenant theology?
options: It expresses Saul’s realization that he has lost divine favor and covenant protection
It indicates Samuel’s betrayal of Saul
It shows that Saul has been excommunicated by the priests
It reflects a common ancient Near Eastern curse
questions.correctAnswer: It expresses Saul’s realization that he has lost divine favor and covenant protection
questions.explanation: This statement in 1 Samuel 28:16 reflects the covenant concept that disobedience leads to loss of God’s presence and protection, signifying Saul’s rejection by God.

questions.question: How does the narrative in 1 Samuel 28 relate intertextually to Deuteronomy 18:10-12, which forbids necromancy?
options: It exemplifies the consequences of violating God's command against necromancy
It legitimizes the practice of consulting spirits in desperate times
It contradicts earlier laws by showing God endorsing necromancy
It is unrelated and only describes historical events
questions.correctAnswer: It exemplifies the consequences of violating God's command against necromancy
questions.explanation: Saul’s downfall after consulting the medium ties back to Deuteronomy 18’s prohibition, showing narrative reinforcement of the law’s seriousness (1 Samuel 28:7-19).

questions.question: What role does the woman’s preparation of a fat calf and unleavened bread in 1 Samuel 28:24-25 play in the story’s cultural context?
options: It demonstrates hospitality and provision despite the illicit nature of the encounter
It represents a sacrificial ritual to invoke spirits
It is a sign of mourning for Saul
It is a bribe to the Philistine army
questions.correctAnswer: It demonstrates hospitality and provision despite the illicit nature of the encounter
questions.explanation: Offering food was a customary act of hospitality in the ancient Near East, showing the woman’s willingness to care for Saul despite the danger (1 Samuel 28:24-25).

questions.question: According to 1 Samuel 28:17-18, what specific disobedience caused God to reject Saul’s kingship?
options: Not executing God’s fierce wrath upon Amalek
Failing to build the temple
Marrying a foreign wife
Taking unauthorized sacrifices
questions.correctAnswer: Not executing God’s fierce wrath upon Amalek
questions.explanation: God’s rejection of Saul is tied to his failure to fully carry out the command against Amalek, as stated in 1 Samuel 28:18.

questions.question: What is the significance of the phrase 'to morrow shalt thou and thy sons be with me' spoken by Samuel in 1 Samuel 28:19?
options: It foreshadows Saul’s imminent death and joining Samuel in the afterlife
It predicts David’s death in battle
It encourages Saul to repent and live
It signifies a political alliance
questions.correctAnswer: It foreshadows Saul’s imminent death and joining Samuel in the afterlife
questions.explanation: Samuel’s prophecy in 1 Samuel 28:19 clearly predicts Saul’s death in the upcoming battle and his joining Samuel in death.

theological.title: 1 Samuel Chapter 28 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from 1 Samuel Chapter 28 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What was the condition of Saul's communication with God at the time of the Philistine threat?
options: God did not answer him by dreams, Urim, or prophets
God answered him clearly through prophets
God sent an angel to encourage him
God spoke to him in a burning bush
questions.correctAnswer: God did not answer him by dreams, Urim, or prophets
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 28:6 states that the LORD answered Saul not by dreams, Urim, or prophets, indicating a withdrawal of divine communication. This reflects themes of God's holiness and judgment seen in Isaiah 59:2 and Hebrews 11:6, where sin separates man from God, and the importance of seeking God rightly as in Jeremiah 29:13 and John 14:6.

questions.question: Why did Saul seek a woman with a familiar spirit despite having removed such practitioners from the land?
options: Because he was desperate for guidance since God was silent
Because he wanted to disobey God openly
Because he wished to test the woman's power
Because he wanted to punish her
questions.correctAnswer: Because he was desperate for guidance since God was silent
questions.explanation: Verses 7 and 15 show Saul's desperation: he sought the medium because God was silent and he was distressed about the coming battle. This reveals the human tendency to seek forbidden help when God seems absent (Deuteronomy 18:10-12 condemns necromancy, while Psalm 34:18 shows God is near the brokenhearted).

questions.question: What does Samuel's rebuke to Saul reveal about God's relationship with Saul?
options: The LORD has departed from Saul and become his enemy
The LORD is still with Saul but silent
The LORD has forgiven all Saul's sins
The LORD is preparing Saul for victory
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD has departed from Saul and become his enemy
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 28:16 clearly states that the LORD has departed from Saul and is now his enemy, reflecting divine judgment for persistent disobedience. This parallels God's rejection of Israel in Hosea 4:17 and the severe consequences of rebellion in Romans 1:18-21, emphasizing God's holiness and justice.

questions.question: What was the divine reason given for the LORD's judgment against Saul?
options: Saul disobeyed God's command to destroy Amalek
Saul worshipped other gods
Saul oppressed the poor
Saul refused to build the temple
questions.correctAnswer: Saul disobeyed God's command to destroy Amalek
questions.explanation: Verse 18 states Saul was judged because he did not obey the voice of the LORD nor execute His fierce wrath on Amalek. This connects to God's holiness and justice in dealing with sin (Exodus 17:14, 1 Samuel 15:22-23, and Romans 6:23), showing the seriousness of partial obedience.

questions.question: What eschatological message did Samuel convey to Saul about the coming battle?
options: Saul and his sons will die and Israel will be delivered into Philistine hands
Saul will triumph and restore Israel's kingdom
Saul will be captured but spared
Saul will find a new kingdom in exile
questions.correctAnswer: Saul and his sons will die and Israel will be delivered into Philistine hands
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 28:19 predicts Saul's death along with his sons and Israel's defeat, illustrating divine judgment and the fulfillment of God's sovereign plan. This reflects biblical eschatology about God's justice and the fate of evildoers (Psalm 37:28, Daniel 12:1-2, Revelation 20:11-15).

questions.question: How did Saul respond physically and emotionally to the words of Samuel?
options: He fell to the ground in fear and lost all strength
He rejoiced and prepared for battle
He ignored the message and left quickly
He became angry and cursed the woman
questions.correctAnswer: He fell to the ground in fear and lost all strength
questions.explanation: Verse 20 describes Saul falling on the earth, being sore afraid, and lacking strength, which illustrates the overwhelming weight of divine judgment and human despair. This aligns with biblical depictions of fear before God’s judgment as in Exodus 34:29-30 and Luke 24:37.

questions.question: What theological significance does the episode with the medium at Endor hold regarding the afterlife?
options: It suggests the reality of the soul's existence after death
It endorses necromancy as a spiritual practice
It denies any form of life after death
It implies that Samuel was resurrected
questions.correctAnswer: It suggests the reality of the soul's existence after death
questions.explanation: The appearance of Samuel's spirit (verses 11-14) implies the soul’s continued existence after death, consistent with Old Testament views (Ecclesiastes 12:7) and New Testament affirmations of the soul's immortality (Luke 16:19-31, 2 Corinthians 5:8). It does not endorse necromancy, which is condemned (Leviticus 19:31).

questions.question: What does the woman's reaction to seeing Samuel's spirit indicate about the nature of this event?
options: She was terrified and recognized Saul
She was joyful and praised God
She was indifferent and confused
She immediately killed Saul
questions.correctAnswer: She was terrified and recognized Saul
questions.explanation: Verse 12 shows the woman cried out loudly, recognizing Saul despite his disguise, indicating the supernatural and fearful nature of the event. This reaction underscores the seriousness of contacting the dead (Leviticus 20:27) and the fear of God's judgment (Psalm 34:7).

questions.question: In what way did Saul disguise himself before visiting the medium, and why is this significant?
options: He put on other clothes to conceal his identity
He wore armor to intimidate the woman
He disguised himself as a priest
He did not disguise himself
questions.correctAnswer: He put on other clothes to conceal his identity
questions.explanation: Verse 8 states Saul disguised himself with different garments, showing his fear of being recognized and punished, which reflects his inner conflict and desperation. This contrasts with God's call for boldness (Acts 4:29) and highlights the shame associated with sin.

questions.question: What promise did Saul make to the woman regarding her safety?
options: He swore by the LORD she would not be punished
He promised to reward her with gold
He threatened her if she lied
He made no promise
questions.correctAnswer: He swore by the LORD she would not be punished
questions.explanation: Verse 10 records Saul swearing by the LORD that no harm would come to her, reflecting a solemn oath invoking God's name and revealing Saul’s anxiety about the consequences of his forbidden act. This connects to biblical teachings on the seriousness of oaths (Matthew 5:34-37).

questions.question: What was Saul's reason for summoning Samuel's spirit according to his own words?
options: He was greatly distressed and had no answer from God
He wanted to confirm his kingship
He wished to curse David
He desired to repent and seek forgiveness
questions.correctAnswer: He was greatly distressed and had no answer from God
questions.explanation: Verse 15 shows Saul’s distress and his statement that God no longer answers him by prophets or dreams, showing his desperation and spiritual isolation. This underscores the consequences of rejecting God’s prophets (Hebrews 11:32-40) and the need for God’s guidance (Psalm 25:4-5).

questions.question: What does the chapter imply about the consequences of Saul's disobedience on Israel as a nation?
options: Israel will be delivered into the hands of their enemies
Israel will remain victorious despite Saul's sin
Israel will exile Saul but prosper
Israel will build a temple instead
questions.correctAnswer: Israel will be delivered into the hands of their enemies
questions.explanation: Verse 19 states that Israel will be delivered into the Philistines' hands, illustrating communal consequences of leadership sin, consistent with biblical principles of corporate responsibility (2 Samuel 12:13-14, Exodus 20:5).

questions.question: How did Saul's servants and the woman respond when Saul refused to eat after the encounter?
options: They compelled him, and he finally ate
They left him alone to fast
They prayed for him to eat
They mocked his fear
questions.correctAnswer: They compelled him, and he finally ate
questions.explanation: Verses 22-23 recount Saul refusing to eat, but his servants and the woman compelled him, showing care and concern despite his distress. This echoes biblical themes about physical sustenance and strength (1 Kings 19:5-8, Matthew 4:4).

questions.question: What symbolic act did the woman perform after Saul agreed to eat?
options: She killed a fat calf and baked unleavened bread
She poured oil on Saul's head
She sang a song of deliverance
She anointed Saul with wine
questions.correctAnswer: She killed a fat calf and baked unleavened bread
questions.explanation: Verses 24-25 describe the woman killing a fat calf and baking unleavened bread, possibly signifying an offering or hospitality. Leaven often symbolizes sin (1 Corinthians 5:7-8), and unleavened bread recalls purity and God's deliverance (Exodus 12:15-20).

questions.question: What does the chapter teach about God's sovereignty over the kingdom of Israel?
options: God has decided to remove Saul and give the kingdom to David
God will allow Saul to reign indefinitely
God's kingdom is dependent on Saul's military success
God has no role in choosing Israel's king
questions.correctAnswer: God has decided to remove Saul and give the kingdom to David
questions.explanation: Verse 17 declares the LORD's will to remove the kingdom from Saul and give it to David, emphasizing divine sovereignty in governance (1 Chronicles 29:11, Romans 13:1-2, Psalm 75:6-7). This affirms God's control over history and leadership.

questions.question: What theological lesson can be drawn from Saul’s refusal to obey God’s commands and subsequent downfall?
options: Disobedience to God leads to judgment and loss of blessing
Disobedience is acceptable if one prays afterward
God always forgives without consequences
Human kingship is more important than divine commands
questions.correctAnswer: Disobedience to God leads to judgment and loss of blessing
questions.explanation: The chapter illustrates in verses 17-19 how Saul’s disobedience results in divine judgment, consistent with biblical teachings on sin and its consequences (Deuteronomy 28, Proverbs 3:5-6, Hebrews 10:26-31). This highlights God's justice and holiness.
